hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with fortune cookies that's right

i'm going to show you how to make your
very own fortune cookies at home which

is a surprisingly simple operation and
not only is this an easy recipe that

produces a very tasty thin crispy cookie
but it's also a lot of fun since we get

to put any messages we want inside i
mean the mind reels with possibilities

so with that let's go ahead and get
started and what we'll need to do before

we start making our cookies is prepare
our fortunes which you're gonna have to

compose print out and then cut up into a
size that will fit inside your cookie

and to make life easier the smaller the
better so once I cut in between these

I'll probably also trim off a little bit
from the ends and traditionally as the

name might indicate these are generally
like some kind of prediction for the

future but nowadays that's usually not
the case they tend to be more along the

lines of deep thoughts or cryptic
observations for example something like

no matter where you go there you are or
a broken cookie will tell you nothing

but a broken heart will so true or learn
from your mistakes but maybe not so

often okay so you'll have to go ahead
and create a bunch of those and if you

get stuck just use some old Chinese
restaurant classics like you're about to

embark on a great adventure or this next
year will bring you great fame and

fortune which are a little cliche but at
least they'll give your guests some

false hope and that's it once we have
our fortunes done we can move on to this

extremely simple batter which is going
to consist of one egg white which we

will separate into this bowl and by the
way unlike when we're making meringue if

you get a little bit of the yolk in this
you don't have to throw it out it's

going to be fine and then to that we
will add some white sugar a little

splash of milk and by the way I used
almond milk which is why it's now white

we will also do a little bit of pure
real vanilla extract as well as some

element extract and if you want some
folks even put a little bit of sesame

oil in this we will also want to add a
little pinch of salt and then we'll

finish up the wet ingredients with a
little bit of melted butter and we'll go

ahead and take a whisk and give that a
mix

and then once our mixture is nice and
smooth and we can feel that all that

sugars been dissolved we will stop and
add the last ingredient some all-purpose

flour and we will go ahead and whisk
that in to create a very very soft semi

runny spreadable batter and keep in mind
if this batter is too thin your cookies

will be very fragile and hard to work
with but we don't want it too thick

either because then we'll end up with
just like a sugar cookie so you're about

to see the texture I like to go for and
it will be up to you to adjust with

either a little more flour or a little
more milk or water

I mean you are after all the Confucious
of your batters looseness so just if you

have to but ultimately you want to end
up with something that looks and feels

like this and then once that's at well
go ahead and transfer on about a

tablespoon or so onto a Silpat lined
baking sheet and we'll use the back of

our spoon to spread that out nice and
thin into a circle about four inches or

so and I'm just gonna do two per pan for
filming purposes but once you get the

swing of this you could probably do four
per pan but anyway we will spread that

batter out into a circular shape as
shown making sure we knock down any

larger Peaks and sometimes that helps
settle it if you want to give it the OL

hole tap a tappa which is really more of
a bang and or a little shake go ahead

but to be honest I don't know if that
does too much although it does feel

pretty good and that's it our batter is
now ready to transfer into the center of

a 350 degree oven for about ten minutes
or so or until 50 to 75% of the cookie

is browned
at which point pay attention because we

have to move fast and what we'll do with
the help of a spatula is make sure

that's loosened from the pan and then we
will place one fortune inside and fold

it over exactly in half or at least
attempt to

and then what we'll do is sort of press
those edges together and then somehow

pick up the cookie and bend it directly
in half on the edge of the pan sort of

folding it like this and then so it
holds its shape while it cools we're

gonna have to put it into some kind of
ramekin or muffin tin and you want to

leave it there until it cools at which
point you can check out the final shape

which you know is not that good all
right I'm not good at a lot of things

and one of them is fortune cookie
forming but for our first one that is

not bad and you'll see you'll get a lot
better at these as you do them okay so

let's move to the next one which because
I took so long with the first one and

was moving the camera and stuff is now
too stiff to fold because it's cooled

but what we can do is pop that back into
the oven for a few minutes until it

softens up again at which point we
should be able to shave it okay so we'll

place our fortune in and we'll fold it
over and kind of press those edges

together the best we can and then we'll
bend it over the edge of the pan oh and

as we're folding this we're trying to
get that outside edge to kind of curl up

a little bit so that we get more of that
signature fortune cookie shape so that

one was a little better still not great
but pretty good and that's it

we will simply continue on until our
batters gone and like I said the more

you do the better you get and as far as
portioning goes a one egg white recipe

which is what we did will make between
10 and 12 fortune cookies depending on

the size which should easily cover your
average dinner party and as I mentioned

once you bend that on the edge of the
pan you sort of want to try to get those

outside edges to curl up a little to
form sort of a brim which will

definitely make these look a little
better and more authentic and by the way

if you're wondering if this is kind of
painful and I'm burning the tips of my

fingers yes a little bit but I have
fairly calloused fingers so it really

wasn't that bad but if you don't feel
free to use some gloves and by the way

don't be in a big hurry to pull those
out and see your shape or I let them

cool because if you pull them out when
they're still warm they're gonna kind of

spread open so be sure to let those cool
before you pull them out and again if

you don't have this sized ramekin just a
good old-fashioned muffin tin will work

the same and that's it before you know
you're gonna have a beautiful plate of

homemade fortune cookies
which are now ready to crack open so

they can reveal their words of wisdom so
